row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, how much chocolate will each person get if 3 people share 1/2 lb of chocolate equally? How many 1/3-cup servings are in 2 cups of raisins?

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators. For example, 2/3 + 5/4 = 8/12 + 15/12 = 23/12. (In general, a/b + c/d = (ad + bc)/bd.),Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically.
row.CCSSDesc: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection. For example, 3x + 2y = 5 and 3x + 2y = 6 have no solution because 3x + 2y cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment’s endpoints.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Functions: Analyze functions using different representations.
row.CCSSDesc: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Multiply and divide within 100.
row.CCSSDesc: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators. For example, 2/3 + 5/4 = 8/12 + 15/12 = 23/12. (In general, a/b + c/d = (ad + bc)/bd.),Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers. For example, recognize an incorrect result 2/5 + 1/2 = 3/7, by observing that 3/7 < 1/2.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.,Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for 4 ÷ (1/5), and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that 4 ÷ (1/5) = 20 because 20 × (1/5) = 4.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Identify important quantities in a practical situation and map their relationships (e.g., using diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, or formulas). (DOK 1, 2, 3)
row.CCSSDesc: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volume of cylinders, cones, and spheres.
row.CCSSDesc: Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
row.CCSSDesc: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand congruence and similarity using physical models, transparencies, or geometry software.
row.CCSSDesc: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.
row.CCSSDesc: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions. For example, apply the distributive property to the expression 3 (2 + x) to produce the equivalent expression 6 + 3x; apply the distributive property to the expression 24x + 18y to produce the equivalent expression 6 (4x + 3y); apply properties of operations to y + y + y to produce the equivalent expression 3y.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.,Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Identify important quantities in a practical situation and map their relationships (e.g., using diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, or formulas).
row.CCSSDesc: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Use operations on fractions for this grade to solve problems involving information presented in line plots. For example, given different measurements of liquid in identical beakers, find the amount of liquid each beaker would contain if the total amount in all the beakers were redistributed equally.,Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: USE EVIDENCE: Cite evidence to support opinions, ideas, or analyses.
row.CCSSDesc: Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources; summarize or paraphrase information in notes and finished work, and provide a list of sources.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: INTERPRET AND INTEGRATE INFORMATION: Locate information to support central ideas and subtopics that are provided; select and integrate information from data or print and non-print text sources for a given purpose.
row.CCSSDesc: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, relfection, and research.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: ANALYZE INFORMATION/SOURCES: Distinguish relevant/irrelevant information.
row.CCSSDesc: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, relfection, and research.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: COMPOSE FULL TEXTS: Write full opinion pieces about topics using a complete writing process attending to purpose and audience: organize ideas by stating a context and focus (opinion); include structures and appropriate transitional strategies for coherence; elaborate and include supporting evidence/reasons from sources; and develop an appropriate conclusion related to the opinion presented.
row.CCSSDesc: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and information. Provide logically ordered reasons that are supported by facts and details.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.”

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Not Applicable,Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step “how many more” and “how many less” problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs. For example, draw a bar graph in which each square in the bar graph might represent 5 pets.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze the adequacy of and make improvements to an existing model or develop a mathematical model of a real phenomenon.
row.CCSSDesc: Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for 4 ÷ (1/5), and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that 4 ÷ (1/5) = 20 because 20 × (1/5) = 4.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Functions: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Number and Quantities: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Functions: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers. For example, the Fibonacci sequence is defined recursively by f(0) = f(1) = 1, f(n+1) = f(n) + f(n-1) for n = 1.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks 1/2 mile in each 1/4 hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction 1/2 / 1/4 miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.,Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Geometry: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles.
row.CCSSDesc: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand the place value system.
row.CCSSDesc: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Write and interpret numerical expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them. For example, express the calculation “add 8 and 7, then multiply by 2” as 2 × (8 + 7). Recognize that 3 × (18932 + 921) is three times as large as 18932 + 921, without having to calculate the indicated sum or product.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.
row.CCSSDesc: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators. For example, 2/3 + 5/4 = 8/12 + 15/12 = 23/12. (In general, a/b + c/d = (ad + bc)/bd.)

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurement from a larger unit to a smaller unit.
row.CCSSDesc: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then –(p/q) = (–p)/q = p/(–q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real world contexts.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.
row.CCSSDesc: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators. For example, 2/3 + 5/4 = 8/12 + 15/12 = 23/12. (In general, a/b + c/d = (ad + bc)/bd.)

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Interpret the structure of expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see x4 – y4 as (x2)2 – (y2)2, thus recognizing it as a difference of squares that can be factored as (x2 – y2)(x2 + y2).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Work with radicals and integer exponents.
row.CCSSDesc: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x^2 = p and x^3 = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that v2 is irrational.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand the place value system.
row.CCSSDesc: Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 × 100 + 4 × 10 + 7 × 1 + 3 × (1/10) + 9 × (1/100) + 2 × (1/1000).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: l approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on the number line diagram, and estimate the value of the expressions (e.g., π2). For example, by truncating the decimal expansion of √2, show that √2 is between 1 and 2, then between 1.4 and 1.5, and explain how to continue on to get better approximations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Define, evaluate, and compare functions.
row.CCSSDesc: nderstand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Identify important quantities in a practical situation and map their relationships (e.g., using diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, or formulas).
row.CCSSDesc: Not Applicable,Not Applicable,Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers. For example, recognize an incorrect result 2/5 + 1/2 = 3/7, by observing that 3/7 < 1/2.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: INTERPRET AND INTEGRATE INFORMATION: Locate information to support central ideas and subtopics that are provided; select and integrate information from data or print and non-print text sources for a given purpose.
row.CCSSDesc: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: ANALYZE/INTEGRATE INFORMATION: Distinguish relevant/irrelevant information.
row.CCSSDesc: Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources; take notes and categorize information, and provide a list of sources.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: USE EVIDENCE: Cite evidence to support opinions, ideas, or analyses.
row.CCSSDesc: Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources; take notes and categorize information, and provide a list of sources.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: COMPOSE FULL TEXTS: Write full informational texts on a topic using a complete writing process attending to purpose and audience: organize ideas by stating a focus (main idea); include text structures and appropriate transitional strategies for coherence; include elaboration and supporting evidence from sources; and develop an appropriate conclusion related to the information or explanation presented.
row.CCSSDesc: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly. Develop the topic with facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples related to the topic.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed. For example, if it took 7 hours to mow 4 lawns, then at that rate, how many lawns could be mowed in 35 hours? At what rate were lawns being mowed?

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Not Applicable,Solve systems of equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Prove theorems about parallelograms. Theorems include: opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Extend understanding of fractions equivalence and ordering.
row.CCSSDesc: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: BAC-MA-v5:NA: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Identify important quantities in a practical situation and map their relationships (e.g., using diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, or formulas). (DOK 1, 2, 3)
row.CCSSDesc: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.,Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples: simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships
row.CCSSDesc: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Number and Quantities: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.
row.CCSSDesc: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.

row.TargetDesc: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.
row.CCSSDesc: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100. For example, rewrite 0.62 as 62/100; describe a length as 0.62 meters; locate 0.62 on a number line diagram.

row.Subject: Math

row.CCSSDesc: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

row.CCSSDesc: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see x4 – y4 as (x2)2 – (y2)2, thus recognizing it as a difference of squares that can be factored as (x2 – y2)(x2 + y2).

row.CCSSDesc: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Geometry: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles.
row.CCSSDesc: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Geometry: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles.
row.CCSSDesc: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem. For example: As a salesperson, you are paid $50 per week plus $3 per sale. This week you want your pay to be at least $100. Write an inequality for the number of sales you need to make, and describe the solutions.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.
row.CCSSDesc: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways. For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand and apply the Pythagorean Theorem.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Represent proportional relationships by equations. For example, if total cost t is proportional to the number n of items purchased at a constant price p, the relationship between the total cost and the number of items can be expressed as t = pn.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volume of cylinders, cones, and spheres.
row.CCSSDesc: Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze the adequacy of and make improvements to an existing model or develop a mathematical model of a real phenomenon.
row.CCSSDesc: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.,Not Applicable,Generate two numerical patterns using two given rules. Identify apparent relationships between corresponding terms. Form ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the two patterns, and graph the ordered pairs on a coordinate plane. For example, given the rule “Add 3” and the starting number 0, and given the rule “Add 6” and the starting number 0, generate terms in the resulting sequences, and observe that the terms in one sequence are twice the corresponding terms in the other sequence. Explain informally why this is so.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions.
row.CCSSDesc: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, create a story context for (2/3) ÷ (3/4) and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient; use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that (2/3) ÷ (3/4) = 8/9 because 3/4 of 8/9 is 2/3. (In general, (a/b) ÷ (c/d) = ad/bc.) How much chocolate will each person get if 3 people share 1/2 lb of chocolate equally? How many 3/4-cup servings are in 2/3 of a cup of yogurt? How wide is a rectangular strip of land with length 3/4 mi and area 1/2 square mi?

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand ration concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.
row.CCSSDesc: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation. For example, in a problem involving motion at constant speed, list and graph ordered pairs of distances and times, and write the equation d = 65t to represent the relationship between distance and time.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Summarize and describe distributions.
row.CCSSDesc: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Work with radicals and integer exponents.
row.CCSSDesc: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions. For example, 3^2 × 3^–5 = 3^–3 = 1/3^3 = 1/27.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.,Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, create a story context for (2/3) ÷ (3/4) and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient; use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that (2/3) ÷ (3/4) = 8/9 because 3/4 of 8/9 is 2/3. (In general, (a/b) ÷ (c/d) = ad/bc.) How much chocolate will each person get if 3 people share 1/2 lb of chocolate equally? How many 3/4-cup servings are in 2/3 of a cup of yogurt? How wide is a rectangular strip of land with length 3/4 mi and area 1/2 square mi?

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: ANALYZE/INTEGRATE INFORMATION: Analyze information within and among sources of information (print and non-print texts, data sets, conducting procedures, etc.).
row.CCSSDesc: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: EVALUATE INFORMATION/SOURCES: Use reasoning, evaluation, and evidence to assess the credibility and accuracy of each source in order to gather and select information to support analysis, reflection, and research.
row.CCSSDesc: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: USE EVIDENCE: Cite evidence to support arguments, ideas, or analyses.
row.CCSSDesc: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of science and technical texts.

row.Subject: ELA/literacy
row.TargetDesc: COMPOSE FULL TEXTS: Write full arguments about topics using the complete writing process: establish and support a claim; organize, elaborate, and cite supporting evidence from credible sources; provide appropriate transitional strategies for coherence; and develop a conclusion that is appropriate to purpose and audience and follows and supports the argument(s) presented.
row.CCSSDesc: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence. Introduce claim(s), acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks 1/2 mile in each 1/4 hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction 1/2 / 1/4 miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples: simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve well-posed problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Not Applicable,Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions. For example, 3^2 × 3^–5 = 3^–3 = 1/3^3 = 1/27.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze the adequacy of and make improvements to an existing model or develop a mathematical model of a real phenomenon.
row.CCSSDesc: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.
row.CCSSDesc: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Multiply and divide within 100.
row.CCSSDesc: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Statistics and Probability: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable.
row.CCSSDesc: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand division as an unknown-factor problem. For example, find 32 ÷ 8 by finding the number that makes 32 when multiplied by 8.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Extend understanding of fractions equivalence and ordering.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Develop understanding of statistical variability.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationship between them.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.,Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.,Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Identify important quantities in a practical situation and map their relationships (e.g., using diagrams, two-way tables, graphs, flowcharts, or formulas). (DOK 1, 2, 3)
row.CCSSDesc: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.,Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection. For example, 3x + 2y = 5 and 3x + 2y = 6 have no solution because 3x + 2y cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.,Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the similarity between them.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.,Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Construct, autonomously, chains of reasoning that will justify or refute propositions or conjectures.
row.CCSSDesc: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Geometry: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: : Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data.
row.CCSSDesc: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept. For example, in a linear model for a biology experiment, interpret a slope of 1.5 cm/hr as meaning that an additional hour of sunlight each day is associated with an additional 1.5 cm in mature plant height.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.2 Examples: If 6 × 4 = 24 is known, then 4 × 6 = 24 is also known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 × 5 × 2 can be found by 3 × 5 = 15, then 15 × 2 = 30, or by 5 × 2 = 10, then 3 × 10 = 30. (Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8 × 5 = 40 and 8 × 2 = 16, one can find 8 × 7 as 8 × (5 + 2) = (8 × 5) + (8 × 2) = 40 + 16 = 56. (Distributive property.)

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Test propositions or conjectures with specific examples.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.
row.CCSSDesc: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.,Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply mathematics to solve problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed. For example, if it took 7 hours to mow 4 lawns, then at that rate, how many lawns could be mowed in 35 hours? At what rate were lawns being mowed?

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.2 Examples: If 6 × 4 = 24 is known, then 4 × 6 = 24 is also known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 × 5 × 2 can be found by 3 × 5 = 15, then 15 × 2 = 30, or by 5 × 2 = 10, then 3 × 10 = 30. (Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8 × 5 = 40 and 8 × 2 = 16, one can find 8 × 7 as 8 × (5 + 2) = (8 × 5) + (8 × 2) = 40 + 16 = 56. (Distributive property.)

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.
row.CCSSDesc: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two-dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category. For example, all rectangles have four right angles and squares are rectangles, so all squares have four right angles.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Distinguish correct logic or reasoning from that which is flawed, and—if there is a flaw in the argument—explain what it is.
row.CCSSDesc: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation, with special attention to the points (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze the adequacy of and make improvements to an existing model or develop a mathematical model of a real phenomenon.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions. For example, apply the distributive property to the expression 3 (2 + x) to produce the equivalent expression 6 + 3x; apply the distributive property to the expression 24x + 18y to produce the equivalent expression 6 (4x + 3y); apply properties of operations to y + y + y to produce the equivalent expression 3y.,Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
row.CCSSDesc: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions. For example, apply the distributive property to the expression 3 (2 + x) to produce the equivalent expression 6 + 3x; apply the distributive property to the expression 24x + 18y to produce the equivalent expression 6 (4x + 3y); apply properties of operations to y + y + y to produce the equivalent expression 3y.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
row.CCSSDesc: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use the technique of breaking an argument into cases.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Interpret results in the context of a situation.
row.CCSSDesc: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.,Not Applicable

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Analyze the adequacy of and make improvements to an existing model or develop a mathematical model of a real phenomenon.
row.CCSSDesc: Not Applicable,Use functions to model relationships between quantities.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: State logical assumptions being used.
row.CCSSDesc: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples: simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.,Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Base arguments on concrete referents such as objects, drawings, diagrams, and actions.
row.CCSSDesc: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.,Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: At later grades, determine conditions under which an argument does and does not apply. (For example, area increases with perimeter for squares, but not for all plane figures.)
row.CCSSDesc: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear. For example, the function A = s^2 giving the area of a square as a function of its side length is not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4) and (3,9), which are not on a straight line.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.
row.CCSSDesc: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.
row.CCSSDesc: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.

row.Subject: Math
row.TargetDesc: Algebra: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning.
row.CCSSDesc: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.
